facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 166 and 167 of 1962 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 166 and 167 of 1962. Appeals from the judgment and decrees dated

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and decrees dated October 25, 1957 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeals Nos. 140 and 139 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decrees dated October 25, 1957 of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeals Nos. 140 and 139 of 1957.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 26, 1963 by WANCHOO J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. April 26. The judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.-These two appeals

facts.text: Deoki Nandan is the lessee of two plots in Anwarganj, Bans Mandi, Kanpur for 99 years from 1943.

anchor.surface_text: Deoki Nandan, appellant in appeal No. 167, is the lessee of two plots in Anwarganj, Bans Mandi, Kanpur, and his lease is for a period of 99 years from 1943.

facts.text: On the plots exists Om Cotton Ginning and Oil Mill, pacca godowns, two-thirds under buildings, one-third open land paved with bricks. No part waste or arable.

anchor.surface_text: On these plots there exists a mill known as Om Cotton Ginning and Oil Mill. Besides the mill there are pacca godowns also on the plots and two-thirds of the area is under buildings while onethird is open land paved with bricks. No part of the land is waste or arable.

facts.text: In February 1932, Government of U.P. sanctioned Pechbagh Dalelpurwa Scheme No. XX by notification of Improvement Trust Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in February 1932 the Government of U. P. sanctioned by numberification a scheme known as Pechbagh Dalelpurwa Scheme No. XX  hereinafter referred to as scheme No. XX  of the Improvement Trust Kanpur.

facts.text: Improvement Trust Kanpur replaced by Development Board Kanpur by Kanpur Urban Area Development Act, No. VI of 1945, repealing U.P. Town Improvement Act, No. III of 1920 for Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the Improvement Trust Kanpur has number been replaced by the Development Board Kanpur  hereinafter referred to as the Board  by the Kanpur Urban Area Development Act, No. VI of 1945,  hereinafter referred to as the Kanpur Act , which repealed the U. P. Town Improvement Act, No. III of 1920, insofar as it applied to Kanpur.

facts.text: Scheme No. XX was not fully carried out after 1932.

anchor.surface_text: It is number clear what happened to scheme No. XX after 1932 but it does appear that it was number fully carried out.

facts.text: In 1955, subsidized industrial housing scheme sponsored by Housing Department of U.P. Government in four phases; fourth phase sanctioned over two crores by Government of India for 6973 tenements, 1368 in Ahata on Hamirpur road.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in 1955 a scheme known as subsidized industrial housing scheme was sponsored by Housing Department of the U. P. Government. This scheme was to be put in force in four phases. and we are companycerned in the present appeal with the fourth phase. For that phase the Government of India had sanctioned over rupees two crores and it was decided to build 6973 tenements of which 1368 were to be in an Ahata on the Hamirpur road.

facts.text: Decision for fourth phase taken by Government of U.P. in May 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The decision in this companynection was taken by the Government of U. P. in May 1955.

facts.text: Notification under s.4 of Land Acquisition Act issued on January 6, 1956 by Governor of U.P. for two plots for construction of tenements in fourth phase and scheme No. XX of Board.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on January 6, 1956, a numberification was issued under s. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act,  No. I of 1894  by the Governor of U. P. to the effect that the two plots in dispute were required for the companystruction of tenements in the fourth phase of the subsidized industrial housing scheme sponsored by the Government of U. P. as well as for general improvement and street scheme No. XX of the Board.

facts.text: Notification under s.6 issued on January 31, 1956, directing urgency under s.17(1) and (1A), Collector to take possession after s.9 notice.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by a numberification under s. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act on January 31, 1956. That numberification further said that the case being one of urgency the Governor was pleased under sub-ss.  1  and  I-A  of s. 17 of the Land Acquisition Act to direct that the companylector of Kanpur, though numberaward under s. 11, has been made, might on the expiration of the numberice mentioned in s. 9  1  take possession of lands, buildings and structures forming part of the land mentioned in the schedule for public purposes.

facts.text: Notice under s.9 issued by Collector on February 10, 1956, possession to be taken on February 25, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Then followed a numberice under s. 9 by the Collector on February 10, 1956, which said that possession would be taken over 15 days after the issue of the numberice i. e. on February 25, 1956.

facts.text: Deoki Nandan filed objections before Collector on February 21, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of this numberice, Deoki Nandan appellant filed his objections before the Collector on February 21, 1956,

facts.text: Deoki Nandan filed writ petition in High Court on February 23, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Two days later, on February 23, 1956, he filed the writ petition in the High Court out of which the present appeal has arisen.

facts.text: Writ petition dismissed by single judge of High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition was dismissed by the learned Single judge who heard it.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Division Bench of High Court, certificate granted.

anchor.surface_text: Then followed an appeal which was heard by a Division Bench of the High Court. The appeal companyrt upheld the view taken by the learned Single Judge and dismissed the appeal. However, the appeal companyrt granted a certificate as prayed for,

facts.text: No action taken under s.5-A of Land Acquisition Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that numberaction was taken under s. 5-A and numberreport was made as required therein.

facts.text: Land required for planned development.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute before us that the land in the present case was required for planned development.

facts.text: No procedure under Ch. VII of Kanpur Act followed for scheme No. XX.

anchor.surface_text: and it is number in dispute that numbers c procedure was gone through in the present case insofar as scheme No. XX is companycerned ,

issues.text: Whether the acquisition proceedings are bad because action was not taken under the Kanpur Urban Area Development Act (including s.114 and Chapter VII) as the land was for scheme No. XX of the Board

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, it is urged that as the acquisition was for scheme No. XX of the Board, action should have been taken under the Kanpur Act and as this was Dot done the entire proceedings are bad including the issue of the numberifications under s. 4 and s.

issues.text: Whether the notification under s.6 of the Land Acquisition Act could be issued without compliance with s.5A, by invoking s.17(4) in a case involving non-waste or arable land under s.17(1A)

anchor.surface_text: In the second place, it is urged that s. 17  4  companyld number apply in the present case and numbernotification under s. 6 companyld be issued unless s. 5-A had been companyplied with. As numbersuch companypliance was admittedly made,

arguments.claim: Acquisition proceedings are bad because action was not taken under the Kanpur Act (s.114 and Ch.VII) as the land was for scheme No. XX of the Board

anchor.surface_text: In the first place, it is urged that as the acquisition was for scheme No. XX of the Board, action should have been taken under the Kanpur Act and as this was Dot done the entire proceedings are bad including the issue of the notifications under s. 4 and s.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: or the Board, action can only be taken, even though it is the Government which is acquiring the land, under the modified provisions of the Land Acquis

arguments.court_reasoning: Kanpur Act modifications under s.114 apply only to land acquisition by the Board itself under s.71 after finalizing scheme under Ch.VII, not to direct acquisition by Government under LAA even for Board's purpose

arguments.claim: s.17(4) could not apply in this case of non-waste/arable land under s.17(1A), so notification under s.6 invalid without compliance with s.5A

anchor.surface_text: In the second place, it is urged that s. 17 (4) could not apply in the present case and no notification under s. 6 could be issued unless s. 5-A had been complied with. As no such compliance was admittedly made,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e. After such a declaration has been made under s.6, the Co- llector has to take order for acquisition of land. It is marked out, measured and planned

arguments.court_reasoning: s.17(4) applies only to land under s.17(1)/(2) i.e. waste/arable; s.17(1A) merely accelerates possession like s.17(1) but does not extend s.17(4) dispensation of s.5A as no amendment made; s.5A is substantial right

arguments.claim: This was not a case to which the Kanpur Act applied

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition was dismissed by the learned Single judge who heard it. On the first question he held that this was not a case to which the Kanpur Act applied.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: or the Board, action can only be taken, even though it is the Government which is acquiring the land, under the modified provisions of the Land Acquis

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed that Kanpur Act s.114 only for Board's own acquisition under s.71

arguments.claim: s.17(4) applied so no need to comply with s.5A before s.6 notification

anchor.surface_text: On the second question, he held that s. 17 (4) applied and therefore it was not necessary to take proceedings to comply with s. 5-A before issuing a notification under s. 6.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e. After such a declaration has been made under s.6, the Co- llector has to take order for acquisition of land. It is marked out, measured and planned

arguments.court_reasoning: s.17(4) limited to s.17(1)/(2) lands; does not cover s.17(1A)

arguments.claim: Whenever land acquired for the Board, even by Government, must use modified LAA under s.114 based on plain words 'acquisition of land for the Board'

anchor.surface_text: Stress in this connection is laid on the words acquisition of land for the Board in s. 114, and it is said that whenever there is acquisition of land for the Board, action can only be taken, even though it is the Government which is acquiring the land,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: by the Board is also for the Board, there can be numberdoubt that the scheme of the Kanpur Act is that the Board first proceeds under ch. VII, then de

arguments.court_reasoning: s.71 acquisition by Board is also 'for the Board'; s.114 provides the modifications referenced in s.71

arguments.claim: Scheme of Kanpur Act: Board frames scheme under Ch.VII, then acquires under s.71 using modified LAA per s.114; govt direct acquisition under plain LAA

anchor.surface_text: If one looks at the scheme of the Kanpur Act, one finds that ch. VII provides for various kinds of development schemes and the procedure for finalising them. After the scheme is finalised under ch. VII power is given to the Board to purchase the land required for the scheme or take it on lease under s. 70.

arguments.claim: Compliance with s.5A mandatory before s.6 unless dispensed under s.17(4), which requires land under s.17(1)/(2)

anchor.surface_text: It will be clear from this scheme that compliance with the provisions of s. 5-A is necessary before a notification can be issued under s. 6. ... When action is taken under s. 17 (4), it is not necessary to follow the procedure in s. 5-A

arguments.claim: s.17(1A) only imports circumstances/time for possession from s.17(1) for non-waste land but does not make s.17(4) applicable as no amendment to s.17(4)

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that when sub-s. (1) is mentioned in sub-s. (1-A) as introduced by the U. P. Act it only means that the power can be exercised to take possession of land other than waste or arable in the same circumstances and at the same time as it could be exercised with respect to arable or waste land as provided in sub-s. (1), and nothing more

arguments.claim: Right under s.5A is substantial and cannot be taken away indirectly via s.17(1A) referencing s.17(1)

anchor.surface_text: The right to file objections under s. 5-A is a substantial right when a persons property is being threatened with acquisition and we cannot accept that that right can be taken away as if by a side-wind because sub-s. (1-A) mentions sub-s. (1).

arguments.claim: Division Bench upheld Single Judge's view that Kanpur Act inapplicable and s.17(4) permits bypassing s.5A

anchor.surface_text: Then followed an appeal which was heard by a Division Bench of the High Court. The appeal court upheld the view taken by the learned Single Judge and dismissed the appeal.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: or the Board, action can only be taken, even though it is the Government which is acquiring the land, under the modified provisions of the Land Acquis

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed on Kanpur Act; disagreed on s.17(4) application

holdings.text: The Kanpur Act has no application where the acquisition is by the Government under the Land Acquisition Act for public purpose though that purpose may be the purpose of the Board; the contention that the proceedings are bad for non-compliance with Kanpur Act has no force and is rejected.

anchor.surface_text: the Kanpur Act has no application at all., and the Government proceeds to acquire under the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act alone. The contention therefore on behalf of the appellants that the Kanpur Act has not been complied with and therefore the proceedings for acquisition of land are bad has no force and must be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Kanpur Act shows s.114 modifications apply only to Board's own acquisition under s.71 after Ch.VII scheme finalization; government direct acquisition under plain LAA even for Board purposes.

holdings.text: s.17(4) of Land Acquisition Act applies only to land under s.17(1) or (2) i.e. waste or arable land and does not extend to non-waste or arable land under s.17(1A); s.5A cannot be dispensed with for planned development under s.17(1A).

anchor.surface_text: I-A. The power to take possession under sub-section (1) may also be exercised in the case of other than waste or arable land,... It seems to us that when sub-s. (1) is mentioned in sub-s. (1-A) as introduced by the U. P. Act it only means that the power can be exercised to take possession of land other than waste or arable in the same circumstances and at the same time as it could be exercised with respect to arable or waste land as provided in sub-s. (1), and nothing more

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.17(1A) merely imports urgency possession timing from s.17(1) without amending s.17(1) or s.17(4); no explicit inclusion in s.17(4); s.5A substantial right not taken away indirectly; legislature failed to amend if intended.

holdings.text: The notification under s.6 and that part of s.4 notification directing under s.17(4) that s.5A provisions shall not apply are bad, ultra vires and set aside.

anchor.surface_text: the notification under s. 6 and that part of the notification under s. 4, which says that the-Governor was pleased to direct that under sub- s.  4  of s. 17, the provisions of s. 5- A shall not apply, are bad and are hereby set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No compliance with s.5A as s.17(4) inapplicable; proceedings invalid without it.

holdings.text: Rest of the notification under s.4 stands; Government at liberty to proceed further after taking action under s.5A and then issue fresh s.6 notification if so chooses.

anchor.surface_text: Rest of the notification under s. 4 will stand and it will be open to the Government if it so chooses to proceed with the acquisition after action is taken under s. 5-A and thereafter to issue a notification under s. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Only invalid part invoking s.17(4) set aside; valid preliminary notification remains effective for further steps post s.5A.

holdings.text: Appellants to be given opportunity under s.5A notwithstanding expiry of time limit, treating their objections filed before Collector after s.9 notice as objections under s.5A due to Government's misunderstanding of law.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we feel that the appellants should be given an opportunity under s. 5-A now, though the period for making objections provided in that section expired long ago in view of the misunderstanding of the law on the part of the Government by treating the objections made before the Collector after the issue of the notices under s. 9 as objections under s. 5-A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equity in view of government's legal error; substantial right to hearing preserved.

justification_sets.label: Kanpur Urban Area Development Act Section 71(1) support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support defeaters

anchor.surface_text: The appeals must therefore be allowed and the notification under s. 6 and that part of the notification under s. 4, which says that the-Governor was pleased to direct that under sub- s.  4  of s. 17, the provisions of s. 5- A shall number apply, are bad and are hereby set aside. Rest of the notification under s. 4 will stand and it will be open to the Government if it so chooses to proceed with the acquisition after action is taken under s. 5-A and thereafter to issue a numberi- fication under s. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals allowed; notification under s.6 set aside; part of notification under s.4 (directing that s.5A provisions shall not apply) set aside; rest of s.4 notification stands; liberty to Government to proceed after complying with s.5A.
directions: Rest of the notification under s. 4 will stand
It will be open to the Government if it so chooses to proceed with the acquisition after action is taken under s. 5-A and thereafter to issue a notification under s. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act.

The appellants should be given an opportunity under s. 5-A, though the period for making objections provided in that section expired long ago in view of the misunderstanding of the law on the part of the Government by treating the objections made before the Collector after the issue of the notices under s. 9 as objections under s. 5-A.

anchor.surface_text: the Kanpur Act has no application at all., and the Government proceeds to acquire under the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act alone. The contention therefore on behalf of the appellants that the Kanpur Act has not been complied with and therefore the proceedings for acquisition of land are bad has no force and must be rejected.

The appeals must therefore be allowed and the notification under s. 6 and that part of the notification under s. 4, which says that the-Governor was pleased to direct that under sub- s.  4  of s. 17, the provisions of s. 5- A shall number apply, are bad and are hereby set aside. Rest of the notification under s. 4 will stand and it will be open to the Government if it so chooses to proceed with the acquisition after action is taken under s. 5-A and thereafter to issue a numberi- fication under s. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act.
